hints_html: You can determine the solution of a system from its row-reduced form. Parametric just means you keep carrying the variable t, so your solution is a general formula that gives the solution of the system in terms of t.
hints_latex:
You can determine the solution of a system from its row-reduced form.
Parametric just means you keep carrying the variable \emph{t}, so your
solution is a general formula that gives the solution of the system in
terms of \emph{t}.
hints_raw: You can determine the solution of a system from its row-reduced form. Parametric just means you keep carrying the variable ''t'', so your solution is a general formula that gives the solution of the system in terms of ''t''.
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
In the first part of the question, we calculated the row reduced form of the augmented matrix of the system and obtained:

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & -1 \\ 0 & 0 & t & -1 \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]

For which we saw that unless t = 0, there is always a unique solution (since the matrix has full rank in that case).

The third row of the matrix translates into

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle tx_3 = -1\end{aligned}\]

Which is equivalent to

\[\begin{aligned} x_3 = -\frac{1}{t}\end{aligned}\]

(recall that we suppose here that t is NOT equal to 0.)

The second row gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x_2 +x_3 = -1\end{aligned}\]

and so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x_2 -\frac{1}{t} = -1\end{aligned}\]

which gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x_2 = -1 +\frac{1}{t} = \frac{1-t}{t}\end{aligned}\]

And finally, the first row gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_3 = 1\end{aligned}\]

Substituting for x2 and x3 we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x_1 + \frac{2(1-t)}{t} - \frac{3}{t} = 1\end{aligned}\]

And hence

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x_1 = \frac{t-2(1-t)+3}{t} = \frac{3t+1}{t}\end{aligned}\]

And we obtain that the system has a unique solution (when t is not zero) which depends on t and the solution is

\[\begin{aligned} \left[ \begin{array}{c} x_1 \\ \\ x_2 \\ \\ x_3 \end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c} \frac{3t+1}{t} \\ \\ \frac{1-t}{t} \\ \\ -\frac{1}{t} \end{array} \right]\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
In the first part of the question, we calculated the row reduced form of the augmented matrix of the system and obtained:
:<math>
\left[ \begin{array}{cccc}
1 & 2 & 3 & 1 \\
0 & 1 & 1 & -1 \\
0 & 0 & t & -1
\end{array} \right]
</math>
For which we saw that unless ''t'' = 0, there is always a unique solution (since the matrix has full rank in that case).

The third row of the matrix translates into
:<math>\displaystyle
tx_3 = -1
</math>
Which is equivalent to
:<math>
x_3 = -\frac{1}{t}
</math>
(recall that we suppose here that ''t'' is NOT equal to 0.)

The second row gives
:<math>\displaystyle
x_2 +x_3 = -1
</math>
and so 
:<math>\displaystyle
x_2 -\frac{1}{t} = -1
</math>
which gives
:<math>\displaystyle
x_2 = -1 +\frac{1}{t} = \frac{1-t}{t}
</math>

And finally, the first row gives
:<math>\displaystyle
x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_3 = 1
</math>
Substituting for ''x''<sub>2</sub> and ''x''<sub>3</sub> we obtain
:<math>\displaystyle
x_1 + \frac{2(1-t)}{t} - \frac{3}{t} = 1
</math>
And hence
:<math>\displaystyle
x_1 = \frac{t-2(1-t)+3}{t} = \frac{3t+1}{t}
</math>

And we obtain that the system has a unique solution (when ''t'' is not zero) which depends on ''t'' and the solution is
:<math>
\left[ \begin{array}{c}
x_1 \\
\\
x_2 \\
\\
x_3
\end{array} \right] = \left[ \begin{array}{c}
\frac{3t+1}{t} \\
\\
\frac{1-t}{t} \\
\\
-\frac{1}{t}
\end{array} \right]
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the system of equations in the variables x1, x2, x3:

\[\begin{aligned} &x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_3 &= 1\\ &x_1 + x_2 + 2x_3 &= 2\\ &2x_1 + 3x_2 + (5+t)x_3 &= 2\end{aligned}\]

For those t for which the system is consistent, give the solution set in parametric form.
statement_latex:
Consider the system of equations in the variables
\emph{x}\textsubscript{1}, \emph{x}\textsubscript{2},
\emph{x}\textsubscript{3}:

\begin{align*}
&x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_3 &= 1\\
&x_1 + x_2 + 2x_3 &= 2\\
&2x_1 + 3x_2 + (5+t)x_3 &= 2
\end{align*} For those \emph{t} for which the system is consistent,
give the solution set in parametric form.
statement_raw:
Consider the system of equations in the variables ''x''<sub>1</sub>, ''x''<sub>2</sub>, ''x''<sub>3</sub>:
:<math>
\begin{align}
&x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_3 &= 1\\
&x_1 + x_2 + 2x_3 &= 2\\
&2x_1 + 3x_2 + (5+t)x_3 &= 2
\end{align}
</math>
For those ''t'' for which the system is consistent, give the solution set in parametric form.
